name: Senator Dick Durbin
tweet_text: Long after we have left the Senate, history will ask where we were when America broke down what seemed like an impossible racial barrier. I will be proud to say I was on this Senate floor, casting my vote for the next Associate Justice of the Supreme Court: Ketanji Brown Jackson.

name: Senator Dick Durbin
tweet_text: This moment is possible because of Judge Jackson and who she is. Her qualifications, her dignity, her integrity, and her record of excellence.

name: Senator Dick Durbin
tweet_text: Our struggle to enfranchise and empower women continues to this day. And with Judge Jackson’s confirmation, we are not just making history—we are elevating one of our nation’s brightest legal minds to an honored position of service. Judge Jackson is the best of us.

name: Senator Dick Durbin
tweet_text: When the Supreme Court first met in this Capitol building in February of 1801, there were a million slaves in this nation of five million people. This very building was built with the labor of enslaved people, and Black women would only enter to clean it in the dark of night.

name: Senator Dick Durbin
tweet_text: The integrity of our free elections, the right to have your vote counted, and our oath to uphold and defend the Constitution count for more. I’m sorry more of my colleagues don’t agree with that basic premise.

name: Senator Dick Durbin
tweet_text: Unfortunately, a majority of Senators have pledged allegiance to the filibuster. But I believe there is something more critical than a Senate rule that has been changed 160 times in the history of this body.

name: Senator Dick Durbin
tweet_text: The Republican-led attacks on voting rights and the fair administration of our elections are shaking the pillars of our democracy. Without federal action to combat this threat, the credibility of our elections and the peaceful transfer of power are at stake.

In 2006, the Senate voted 98-0 to reauthorize and strengthen the Voting Rights Act. 16 current Senate Republicans voted yes.
